content.value: Fibre includes the parts of plant foods that your body can't digest or absorb. Unlike other food components, such as fats, proteins or carbohydrates — which your body breaks down and absorbs — fibre isn't digested by your body. Instead, it passes relatively intact through your stomach, small intestine and colon and out of your body.
Fibre comes in two forms: Soluble and Insoluble.

Insoluble fibre promotes the movement of material through your digestive system and increases stool bulk, because of this, it benefits those who struggle with constipation or irregular stools. Whole-wheat flour, wheat bran, nuts, beans and vegetables, such as cauliflower, green beans and potatoes, are good sources of insoluble fibre.
The amount of soluble and insoluble fibre fluctuates between different plant foods. To achieve the greatest health benefit, eat a wide variety of high-fibre foods.
Excellent source of Vitamin C.
Kale is very high in nutrients and very low in calories.
Very high in Vitamin K, an important nutrient, that is involved in blood clotting.

Kale is among the most nutrient dense foods on the planet, as it is high in nutrients and very low in calories. Including more kale in your diet is an effective way to dramatically increase the total nutrient content of your diet. Similar to other leafy greens, Kale is very high in antioxidants such as beta-carotene and Vitamin C, which help counteract oxidative damage by free radicals in the body.

Known as the the sunshine vitamin, Vitamin D, is actually not a vitamin, rather, it is considered a pro-hormone, as it is produced in the human body. Vitamin D is absent from all natural foods except fish and egg yolks, and even when it's obtained from foods, it must be transformed by the body before it can be  absorbed. This hormone is required in order to absorb Calcium which is vital for the development of strong bones.

Calcium, the most abundant mineral in the body, plays an important role in maintaining strong bones and healthy blood vessels. It is also known to reduce the risk of Type 2 diabetes. Low levels of calcium may play a role in PMS-related depression in particular. Calcium deficiency affects more women than men, so women should take special care to meet the daily requirements.

Vitamin B1, or thiamin, helps prevent complications in the nervous system, brain, muscles, heart, stomach, and intestines. It is also involved in the flow of electrolytes into and out of muscle and nerve cells.
There are high concentrations of Vitamin B1 in the outer layers and germ of cereals, as well as in yeast, beef, pork, nuts, whole grains, and pulses.
Fruit and vegetables that contain it include cauliflower, liver, oranges, eggs, potatoes, asparagus, and kale.
Other sources include brewer’s yeast and blackstrap molasses.
Breakfast cereals and products made with white flour or white rice may be enriched with Vitamin B.

Vitamin B2, or riboflavin, is one of eight B vitamins that are essential for human health. It can be found in grains, plants, and dairy products. It is crucial for breaking down proteins, fats, and carbohydrates. Vitamin B2 also plays a vital role in maintaining the body's energy supply.

Niacin, also known as Vitamin B3, is essential for general good health. Every part of your body needs it to function properly. This water-soluble supplement may help boost brain function, among other benefits.

Many people are able to get the amount of niacin they need by eating a healthy diet. It occurs naturally in many foods, such as, greens, meat, poultry, fish, and eggs. Many products are also fortified with niacin during manufacturing.
Niacin can also be used as a treatment to improve cholesterol levels.

If your doctor prescribes Niacin, you might want to take it with food. This can prevent an upset stomach. To reduce flushing, your health care provider may recommend taking Niacin along with aspirin or avoiding drinking alcohol.

Pyridoxine, also known as Vitamin B6 is one of the B vitamins necessary for metabolism, proper functioning of the brain and liver, physical growth, red blood cell production, skin integrity, and eye health. This vitamin should wear a cape, with superpowers like these!
This water-soluble vitamin flushes through your body daily, as the body can not store it. It is therefore essential that we include it in our everyday diet.
The versatility of Vitamin B6 allows it to function as a co-enzyme in over 100 chemical reactions. Vitamin B6 is assisted by Vitamin B12 and Folate.
Together, this dream team, contributes to the making and functioning of our genetic material (DNA), so they impact every cell in the body.

Vitamin B7, more commonly known as biotin, is a water-soluble vitamin that is essential for the body’s metabolism and functioning. It is an vital component of a number of enzymes responsible for essential metabolic pathways in the human body, including the metabolism of fats and carbohydrates, as well as amino acids involved in protein synthesis.
Biotin is known to promote cell growth and is often a component of dietary supplements used for strengthening hair and nails, as well as those marketed for skincare.

Vitamin B7 is found in a number of foods, though in small amounts. This includes walnuts, peanuts, cereals, milk, and egg yolks. Other foods that contain this vitamin are wholemeal bread, salmon, sardines, mushroom, and cauliflower. It is also present in avocados, bananas, and raspberries. As long as you're eating a healthy varied diet, your body should have sufficient amounts of biotin.

Folate, also known as Vitamin B9, is found in a wide range of foods including vegetables, legumes, eggs, and fruit. However, Folic Acid, the form that is added to foods and supplements, is better absorbed.
Folate is needed to produce healthy red blood cells and is critical during periods of rapid growth, such as during pregnancy and fetal development.

Get your mojo back by asking your doctor to check your B12 levels. If they are on the low side, it’s time to up your intake. If you’re feeling sluggish and you’re not sure why, a lack of Vitamin B12 (Cobalamin) may be to blame.
Vitamin B12 is a nutrient
that helps keep the body’s nerve
and blood cells

healthy and helps make DNA. This water-soluble vitamin aids in red blood cell formation, which prevents against a type of anemia that can often make people feel weak and tired. Vitamin B12 also works with Vitamin B6 and Folate to reduce homocysteine and therefore improve heart health.

Vitamin C, is a powerful antioxidant that serves many vital functions in the body’s cells. It is necessary for the synthesise of collagen, the most abundant structural protein in the body. Which improves the flexibility of arteries, increases blow flow which delivers oxygen and nutrients to your brain. It helps neutralise free radicals that are believed to cause aging of cells. Orange juice, cherries, red peppers, kale, and grapefruit are some examples of foods where this popular vitamin is found.

Vitamin E, is an impressive antioxidant that occurs naturally in foods such as nuts, seeds, and leafy green vegetables. It is required for the proper function of many organs in the body and is key for strong immunity and healthy skin and eyes. It also helps to slow down the aging process by slowing down the processes that damage cells and may help reduce free radical damage.
Vitamin K, also known as, the blood-clotting vitamin, has a pivotal role in healing wounds. The "K" is derived from the German word
koagulation
. The body needs  Vitamin K to produce prothrombin, a protein and clotting factor that is essential in blood clotting and bone metabolism.
This fascinating nutrient can be considered one of the most important nutritional interventions for improving bone density as it serves as a biological glue that plugs Calcium into the bone matrix.
Vitamin K, also teams up with other vitamins. Vitamin K works with vitamin D to ensure that Calcium finds its way to the bones to help them develop properly.
High in Vitamin E.
Lowers blood pressure and sugar levels.
Anti-inflammatory and immunity-boosting.

Largely concentrated in the skin of this delicious nut, antioxidants help to protect your cells. These free radical fighters, defend against the major contributors to aging and disease. It is for this very reason, we like our almonds with their brown coat on.

Become the Creative Director with it comes to this saucy nut. As this nutritious ingredient, can be transformed into many forms. These include Almond Meal, Almond Milk and Almond Butter.

Tip: Add a handful of lightly roasted almonds to your salad or chop and use as a topping for pasta, steamed or healthy sauteed vegetables. When eating foods with a higher glycemic index, including almonds in the meal can help keep your blood sugar under control.

Iron, plays a vital role in immune system function. It is well respected for it's work in boosting hemoglobin levels and treating anemia. Adequate levels of Iron are required to provide oxygen for muscle contraction, which therefore improves muscle strength and recovery. Through supplying oxygen to cells, it also improves concentration and aids in issues with sleep. It's a win win.
Vitamin A compounds are found in both animal and plant foods and come in two different forms: preformed Vitamin A and Provitamin A.
Preformed Vitamin A, is known as the active form of the vitamin, which your body can use just as it is. It’s found in animal products including meat, chicken, fish and dairy.

Provitamin A carotenoids, are the inactive form of the vitamin found in plants. They are converted to the active form in your body. Once converted, theres no denying that you are protected against cell damage.

This essential micronutrient is required for the healthy growth and maintenance of skeletal tissues, skin, and the functioning of the eyes. A healthy diet that incorporates a wide variety of foods such as, colourful vegetables, fruit, whole grains, lean meats, and reduced-fat dairy products is the best way to get enough Vitamin A.
Apples are a good source of fibre and Vitamin C
High in B Vitamins.
Good for gut health.

Keep the doctor away with this powerful fruit. High in soluble fibre, and low in cholesterol, Apples are great for promoting heart health in many ways! Containing high amounts of pectin, which acts as a prebiotic, your brain will always feel fresh and your gut will always be happy.
Tip: Give your apple a good wash and eat it with its skin on, to get the most benefits from this miracle fruit.
Free radical fighter
Boost your memory and regulate mood
Helps to balance blood sugar levels
This sh*t is bananas. B.A.N.A.N.A.S.
Botanically speaking, banana is considered both a herb and a berry. This plant, which is distantly related to ginger, contains more than meets the eye.

Eating a banana is a step in the ripe direction. This cutie is high in fibre, which is largely concentrated in the skin of this delicious fruit. Pectin works to moderate blood sugar levels and promotes gut health by feeding the beneficial bacteria in the digestive tract. Bananas contain tryptophan, an amino acid that may help preserve memory, boost a person’s ability to learn and remember things, and regulate mood. Due to their high antioxidant content, it can also be called free-radical fighter, which acts to defend against the major contributors
to aging and disease.

Tip: Hang your bananas, rather than placing them in a fruit bowl. This will prevent them from bruising and it also decreases the chance of exposing the banana flesh to oxygen, which will make them ripen that much faster.
Best when raw!
Good source of B vitamins.
Promotes healing and protects from cell damage.

Broccoli has a reputation as a superfood and it's no wonder why. Just one cup of cooked broccoli offers as much Vitamin C as an Orange!

This low calorie, fibre packed babe, contains a wealth of nutrients and antioxidants that support many aspects of health. Broccoli belongs to a family of vegetables called cruciferous vegetables and its close relatives include Brussels Sprouts, Cauliflower, and Cabbage. Like her siblings, Broccoli is an all-star food with many health benefits. Broccoli promotes healthy gut bacteria and supports bowel regularity. As if that's not enough, studies show that Broccoli may contain bioactive compounds that have been shown to reduce inflammation your body’s tissues.
Also known as 'Garbanzo Beans'
Contain a significant amount of protein
Chickpeas contain high levels of fibre, protein, vitamins, minerals and other goodies for both your physical and mental health.
Chickpeas, or Garbanzo beans, once only popular in the Middle East and the Mediterranean, are now available all over the world, lucky us!

These very wholesome, nutty, grainy beans, can be served up in multiple ways and goes with pretty much everything. The most common type has a round shape and a beige color, but other varieties are black, green, or red. Their nutrients have various health benefits.

Chickpeas have an impressive nutrition profile. They contain a range of nutrients, including protein, which is necessary for bone, muscle, and skin health. For people who are cutting down on meat consumption, a dish of chickpeas and rice, for example, can contribute a significant amount of protein to the diet.

Eat your way to better Chickpeas contain high levels of choline, which helps with brain and nervous system function. Choline plays a role in mood, muscle control, learning, and memory, as well as the body’s metabolism.
Tip: Pre-soak your dried Chickpeas in salty water before cooking, this makes the beans easier to digest and promotes a faster cook time!
Packed full of protein!
Antioxidant rich and high in Iron
Aids in the formation of healthy red blood cells
First, what is coconut considered? A fruit? A nut? To make things more confusing, coconut can be a fruit, a nut, and a seed. This is called a 'drupe'.

Ok, now that we've got that out of the way... Young coconut meat comes from green coconuts, which aren't fully mature. Given how difficult it is to crack open a coconut, eating raw coconut meat isn't too common — you're more likely to find commercially prepared products, like coconut water or coconut cream, in grocery stores. However, raw coconut is just as good for you as any other form of coconut. In many ways, eating raw coconut is even better as it's full of fibre, vitamins and minerals. It is especially rich with manganese which supports enzyme function and fat metabolism. Coconut is a unique fruit because of its high fat content. Around 89% of the fat in its meat is saturated. Packed full of good stuff, this delicious drupe is a great source of plant-based protein.
Hydration Heroes!
Helps with Digestion and inflammation.
Cucumbers have high amount of Cucurbitacin.
You'll feel as cool as a cucumber when you eat this long, lean, fruit. Technically, they’re fruit from the same family as watermelons and pumpkins, but most people consider them veggies.
There are two main types of cucumbers:
Slicing cucumbers
are eaten fresh, often in a salad. They can be 10-18 cm or longer and usually have smooth skin.  You may also hear them called “seedless cucumbers” or “European cucumbers.”
Pickling cucumbers
are much smaller and are the type used to make pickles. They can be 7 to 10 cm long, and they typically have bumps or spines on their skin.
Cucumbers contain around 95% water. This is important to know, as your cells need enough water to work right

Cucumbers are packed with nutrients. In just a single cup of cucumber slices, you'll get 14% to 19% of the Vitamin K you need for the day. You'll also get Vitamins B and C along with minerals like Copper, Phosphorus, Potassium, and Magnesium.
The "burpless" slicing varieties have less of a plant compound called cucurbitacin. That gives them a milder taste, and it may make you burp less after you eat them.

Tip: Before you wash, slice, and toss your cucumbers into salads, you may want to soak them in salt water first. This will lower the amount of water in them and keep the cucumbers from making your salad dressing watery.
Antioxidant rich and high in Iron
Coconut milk contains Lauric Acid that is known for its antiseptic properties.
Aids in the formation of healthy red blood cells

Coconut Milk, is no average player, when it comes to the game of weight loss. Containing medium-chain triglycerides (MCTs), This milky, white, substance is extracted from the flesh of mature coconuts. But this It can benefit health in several ways, such as by stimulating weight loss and lowering cholesterol. Coconut Milk also boosts the immune system with its antimicrobial and anti-inflammatory properties. It also aids in the formation of healthy red blood cells with its significant quantities of iron.
Antioxidant rich and high in Iron.
Coconut milk contains Lauric Acid that is known for its antiseptic properties.
Aids in the formation of healthy red blood cells

Like Coconut Milk, Coconut Cream containing medium-chain triglycerides (MCTs), This milky, white, substance is extracted from the flesh of mature coconuts. But this It can benefit health in several ways, such as by stimulating weight loss and lowering cholesterol.
Coconut Milk also boosts the immune system with its antimicrobial and
anti-inflammatory properties. It also aids in the formation of healthy red
blood cells with its significant quantities of iron.
Detoxify your skin.
Improves heart and nerve function.
Reduce inflammation and fights infections.

Ranking high on the nutritional chart, Leeks have been regarded as a superfood since the ancient Egyptian era. This heart-friendly food, consists of high amounts of Folate, which helps protect blood vessel linings from damage. Leeks are known to as natural diuretic and detoxify your skin by trapping harmful substances and flushing them out of the body. Leeks also contain a significant amount of Vitamin A, which is vital in maintaining your immune system. This compound is helpful in reducing inflammation and strengthening the body, which helps fight infections. We recommend cutting them very thinly and preparing them by using our Healthy Sauté method of cooking. Like their Allium cousins, Onions and Garlic, let Leeks sit for at least 5 minutes after cutting and before cooking.
Easy and fast legumes!
Contain a powerful amount of fibre!
Contain signification amounts of folate and magnesium.

Lentils are a small but nutritionally mighty member of the legume family! Not only do lentils help to lower cholesterol, but they also have the added benefit of regulating blood sugar levels. But this is far from all lentils have to offer.

When it comes to fibre, lentils lead the pack! Lentils, like other beans, are rich in dietary fibre, both the soluble and insoluble type. This supports regular bowel movements, promotes healthy gut bacteria and also helps prevent digestive disorders such as irritable bowel syndrome and diverticulosis.
In addtion to fibre, lentils supply significant amounts of folate and magnesium.
- Folate is a vitamin responsible for regulating DNA and producing neurotransmitters such as serotonin and dopamine.

- Magnesium is Nature's own calcium channel blocker. When enough magnesium is around, veins and arteries breathe a sigh of relief. As they begin to relax, they lessen resistance, thus improving the flow of blood, oxygen, and nutrients throughout the body.
Lentils are easy to cook. Unlike many other legumes, they don’t require any prior soaking and can be cooked in less than 20 minutes.
They can then be placed in a pot, covered with water and a pinch of salt brought to a boil, and left to simmer uncovered for 15–20 minutes.
Tip: It’s best to give them a rinse before cooking, to eliminate impurities.
Gluten-free
Lower Cholesterol Levels
High amounts of Soluble Fibre (Beta-glucan)

Oats are among the healthiest grains on earth. These gluten-free whole grains come in many with Oat groats being the most intact and healthiest form. They are a great source of important vitamins, minerals, soluble fibre and antioxidants. Oats contain large amounts of beta-glucan, which forms a thick gel which increases absorption of glucose into the blood and feelings of fullness after eating. It also helps reduce cholesterol and blood sugar levels. Is there anything this grain can't do?
High in Vitamin E.
Lowers blood pressure and sugar levels.
Anti-inflammatory and immunity-boosting.
Encluding Almond Milk into your diet may dramatically improve your body. Packed full of Vitamin E, Almonds are key for strong immunity, healthy skin, and eyes.

Some varieties are also fortified with Vitamin D, which is an important nutrient for many aspects of good health, including heart function, bone health, and immune function. Unfortunately, homemade Almond Milk, is not a good source of this nutrient. It is, however, naturally lactose-free, making it a good alternative to dairy.
Maintain your beauty inside and out, by including more Almond Milk in your lifestyle, and you'll be laughing when asked at the checkout when they ask for your I.D.
Tip: Heat up your Almond Milk and add a pinch of Saffron and Cardamom Powder for a Badam style drink.
High in Vitamin E.
Lowers blood pressure and sugar levels.
Anti-inflammatory and immunity-boosting.
Making homemade Almond Meal is so easy!

Simply add sweet whole (usually unpeeled) Almonds to a blender and blitz until a fine, powdery consistency is achieved. Similar to their amigo, Almond Flour, which tends to use peeled Almonds, but perhaps not quite as finely ground. Almond Meal works well as a gluten-free flour in both sweet and savoury recipes. Generally in New Zealand, you’ll find Almond Meal readily available instead of Almond Flour.

Take a ride on the wild side and get your blood pumping with this protein-rich ingredient! Proven to lower blood pressure and improve blood flow, there's no denying that this is the real deal... or rather, the real meal.
Tip: When using Almond Meal made from the leftover pulp in recipes that call for traditional Almond Meal, it is sometimes helpful to compensate with additional water, oil, or fat.
High in Vitamin E.
Lowers blood pressure and sugar levels.
Anti-inflammatory and immunity-boosting.

That’s right. Just a simple change, such as, adding flavoursome Almond Butter to your diet, can greatly improve your overall health. This humble seed butter, whilst, a popular ingredient in candy and baked treats, is packed full of Vitamin E. Reconsider reaching for that old staple of peanut butter and add Almond Butter to your sandwich instead for enhanced immunity, healthy skin and eyes.
Great gluten-free alternative!
Three main types: white, red and black.
One of the few plant foods that contain all nine essential amino acids.

Referred to it as the "mother of all grains". This seed is known for its high protein and amino acid content. It is so high in fact that NASA scientists have been experimenting with it as a suitable crop for long-term sustainability in outer space. No, seriously... this seed is top! The United Nations declared 2013 “The International Year of Quinoa” due to the seeds’ potential to contribute to food security worldwide.
This is due to its high nutrient content, ease of use, and simplicity of growing. The versatile superfood comes in three main types: white, red, and black.
Tip: To maximise the benefits of this complete protein, soak quinoa prior to cooking. This will reduce the Phytic Acid content and make the minerals in this powerful seed, more bioavailable.

Magnesium plays a large role in the development of serotonin, which is a major contributor to feelings of happiness. It's ability to help regulate emotions and balance mood, make it a central element in many homeopathic remedies. This abundant mineral also plays a major role in maintaining and protecting the body's health, due to it being a cofactor in many enzyme systems which help the body  regulate protein synthesis, control blood glucose, and regulate blood pressure.

Potassium is part of every cell in the body, and life would be impossible without it. Often taken for granted, this powerful electrolyte is vital for maintaining fluid balance, and keeping your brain, nerves,
and heart regulating on a constant basis.
Other powerful health benefits include the lowering of blood pressure, sending nerve signals and regulating muscle contractions making it one of the most important minerals in the body.
Eating a potassium-rich diet and staying hydrated is key for maintaining good fluid balance.
Phosphorus is an essential nutrient required for bone health
and many other bodily functions.

You need Phosphorus to keep your bones strong and healthy, to help make energy, and to move your muscles. Phosphorus is the second most abundant mineral in your body  In addition, Phosphorus helps to filter out waste in your kidneys and facilitate nerve conduction.

Manganese is a naturally occurring mineral in our body that acts as a co-enzyme to assist metabolic activities in the human body. It also helps in the formation of connective tissues, and proper functioning of the thyroid gland and sex
hormones. It is an important mineral when it comes to regulation of blood sugar level and proper metabolism of fats and

carbohydrates. Manganese may also help promote strong, dense bones when combined with other nutrients, such as Calcium and Vitamin D. This trace mineral, is vital for the human body, but only need it in small amounts. As the human body cannot produce manganese, a person usually obtains manganese from their diet.

Fibre includes the parts of plant foods that your body can't digest or absorb. Unlike other food components, such as fats, proteins or carbohydrates — which your body breaks down and absorbs — fibre isn't digested by your body. Instead, it passes relatively intact through your stomach, small intestine and colon and out of your body.
Fibre comes in two forms: Soluble and Insoluble.

Soluble fibre dissolves in water to form a gel-like material, to slow down digestion. It improves health by lowering blood cholesterol and glucose levels. It is found in oats, peas, beans, apples, carrots, lentils, and barley. It is also found in psyllium, which is a popular fibre supplement.
The amount of soluble and insoluble fibre fluctuates between different plant foods. To achieve the greatest health benefit, eat a wide variety of high-fibre foods.
Copper is an essential trace mineral necessary for survival. It helps the body form collagen
and absorb iron, and plays a role in energy production.

This mineral enables a normal metabolic process in association with amino acids and vitamins. It cannot be produced by the body and must be included in the daily diet in order to enjoy the health benefits. It is found in all body tissues and plays a role in making red blood cells and maintaining nerve cells and the immune system.
Antibacterial and antimicrobial.
Versatile and can be easily substituted for butter or oil.
Coconut oil contains Lauric Acid that is known for its antiseptic properties.
Coconut oil has grown in popularity in recent years, amid claims that it can do everything from supporting weight loss to slowing the progression of Alzheimer’s disease.

In recent years, the popularity of coconut and particularly coconut oil has soared due to touted health benefits. Fuelling the coconut oil trend, celebrity endorsements have claimed the ingredient to help blast away belly fat, curb appetite, strengthen the immune system, prevent heart disease, and stave off dementia and Alzheimer’s disease. Coconut oil can also be used in oil pulling is a
traditional oral treatment. It involves swishing the oil inside the mouth, in a
similar way to the modern mouthwash. Studies have found coconut oil pulling to
protect against cavities, improve gingivitis, and influence the oral
bacterial balance.
Coconut oil is also great for the skin! Applying a coconut extract to human skin may enhance it's protective barrier functions and have an anti-inflammatory effect.
In addition to this, researchers believe that virgin coconut oil could be useful in treating some kinds of depression.

Tip! Coconut oil has a low melting point and will liquify on a warm day. When substituting for butter, it's suggested to use 25% less coconut oil than the amount of butter listed in the recipe. This is due to it's higher percentage of fat solids.
Another tip is to use refined coconut oil if you don't want a coconut flavour.

It is important to note that, whilst the icons above note that coconut oil contains a variety of vitamins and minerals, coconut oil is almost completely saturated fat. However, the structure of fat in coconut oil differs from that of many animal products, making it a healthier option.
Replenishes electrolytes lost during exercise.
Lower blood sugars and reduce blood pressure.
Coconuts and Coconut Water may prevent kidney stones by reducing crystal and stone formation.

It's no wonder that this trendy beverage, found in the centre of a young, green Coconut, is a considered a hydration hero. Coconut Water forms naturally in the fruit and contains 94% water and very little fat. As the Coconut matures, some of the juice remains in liquid form while the rest ripens into the solid white flesh known as Coconut Meat. High in antioxidants that protect your cells from damage caused by free radicals, Coconut Water may be the perfect beverage for restoring hydration and replenishing electrolytes lost during exercise.
Great for digestive health.
Packed full of antioxidants.
Free radical fighter!

The nutritional profile of cauliflower is quite impressive. Cauliflower is a powerhouse when it comes to nutrients, this low calorie food, contains almost every vitamin and mineral that you need. This cheeky vegetable can strengthen bones, boost the cardiovascular system, and prevent cancer. Try substituting high-calorie foods, such as rice and flour for cauliflower, or take advantage of the vegetable’s considerable antioxidant content, by eating it raw.
Free Radical Fighter!
Eat for clear and glowing skin.
Cheap, available all year round and lasts longer in the fridge than most vegetables

Cabbage, which is often lumped into the same category as lettuce because of their similar appearance, is actually a part of the cruciferous vegetable family. This heart healthy babe is notorious for being chock-full of beneficial nutrients. High in Vitamin C, a potent antioxidant, this cutie may protect against heart disease, certain cancers, and vision loss. Cabbage also helps keep skin looking health, toned, blemish-free and glowing; it’s rich in antioxidants (including Vitamin C and Beta-Carotene). This versatile veggi can be cooked or fermented or enjoyed raw. Red Cabbage in particular might give you the best nutritional boost per serving.

Tip: For a crisper bite that remains even hours after it’s dressed, sprinkle some salt over your chopped cabbage and let it sit in a colander for an hour or two. Then, wring out the cabbage by squeezing it with your hands or putting the cabbage in a muslin/cheese cloth to draw out the extra moisture.
High in Vitamin C.
Also known as Yang Tao or Chinese gooseberry.
Immunity-boosting and aids in digestion.

This hairy fruit is packed with vitamins and minerals. These contribute collectively to the proper functioning of the body such as blood circulation through the vessels, fight stress, iron absorption for healthy bones and teeth, good vision, etc.

Native to China, Kiwifruit were originally known as Yang Tao. They were brought to New Zealand from China by missionaries in the early 20th century with the first commercial plantings occurring several decades later. In 1960, they were renamed Chinese Gooseberries. The name was later changed from Chinese Gooseberry to Kiwifruit, in honour of the native bird of New Zealand, the kiwi, whose brown fuzzy coat resembled the skin of this unique fruit.
Tip: When selecting kiwifruits, hold them between your thumb and forefinger and gently apply pressure; those that have the sweetest taste will yield gently to pressure.
Many different varieties.
Support a healthy digestive system.
Antioxidant with antifungal properties.
Like their delicious cousins, Kale, Broccoli, Cauliflower, and Horseradish, Radishes, are part of the Cabbage Family.

Radishes are a group of root vegetables with variable skin colour, crunchy flesh,  and an almost spicy, peppery taste. They vary in shape from short and round to long and narrow, and the skin can be red, black, white, yellow, pink, or purple. The most common member of this family is the Red Radish, also called 'Round Radish' or 'Globe Radish'. However, this baby is just one variety. Daikon, also known as, White Radish is popular in many Asian cuisines and is not as hot and peppery as the red variety.
Radishes are a natural antifungal agent. Radish juice contains enzymes that kill a common fungus normally found in humans. This fungus
(Candida albicans) c
an cause yeast infections.
Radishes are also packed with roughage and fibre, so they'll help keep your digestive system moving.
Tip: Because they grow rapidly, Radish plants are ideal for children's gardens.
Packed with Lycopene.
Tomatoes may help Fight Prostate Cancer.
Outstanding Antioxidant and Anti-Inflammatory Benefits.
Tomato is a fruit that’s often treated as a vegetable.

This nutrient-dense superfood is usually red when mature, but can also come in a variety of colours, including yellow, orange, green, and purple. What’s more, many subspecies of tomatoes exist with different shapes and flavours.

Tomatoes are loaded with a substance called Lycopene, which gives them their typically bright red color and helps protect them from the ultraviolet rays of the sun. When eaten, Lycopene helps to protect your cells from damage, just like it protects the tomatoes.
Given the rising levels of pollution, our skin and hair can end up dry and damaged. Incorporating tomatoes in your regular diet actually helps to battle the wear and tear our skin goes through.

In addition to this, Lycopene in tomatoes is a potent cancer-fighter and seems to be particularly helpful in the prevention of prostate cancer. The American Cancer Society reported that eating actual tomatoes seems to be more protective than taking a lycopene supplement, wow!
Tip: Combine your tomato recipes with olive oil for greater health benefits, and increased absorption of Lycopene.
Boost your immunity with this versatile fruit!
Capsicum (also known as bell pepper) is an excellent source of Vitamin A and C.
Comes in a multitude of colours such as red, orange, yellow and green.

People often wonder why the different colours can cost differently in the supermarket. 
All capsicum's come from the same plant, it is their degree of ripening that gives them the different colours.

All capsicum's start out as green and therefore they are cheapest, however, the colour you choose should depend on how you are going to use it.

As our vibrant friends mature, they become sweeter and also increase in antioxidant benefits. This is because red capsicums are more mature in terms of ripening and as a result have a much higher carotenoid content than the other colours. Choose red capsicums over the other colours for not only a pop of colour in your meal, but also to ensure that you get the most nutritional value. Rumour has is that red capsicums contains almost twice as many nutrients as their green friends.
Tip: To maximise the goodness you get from a capsicum, mix in capsicums with fat and cook your capsicums, rather than eating them raw.
Hydration Station: These bright red berries have a high water content!
High in Vitamin C and Manganese
Curb your cravings and control blood sugar

Not many things are sweeter than fresh picked strawberries. But, besides being sweet and delicious, strawberries are also packed with nutrients. The heart-shaped silhouette of the strawberry is the first clue that this juicy fruit is good for you. These potent little packages protect your heart, increase good cholesterol and help control your blood sugar. Recent studies have found that a one-cup serving of strawberries has more vitamin C than an Orange. Vitamin C is known for its antioxidant properties, helping to protect the body from oxidative stress.
Reduce inflammation and fights infections.
Energy without the anxiety, crash or jitters.
Boosts the metabolic rate and increase fat burning.

Green tea is more than just liquid. It is loaded with antioxidants and nutrients that have powerful effects on the body. These include improved brain function, fat loss, a lower risk of cancer and many other impressive benefits.

Green tea does more than just keep you awake, it can also make you smarter. It is high in caffeine which can lead to improved mood, vigilance, reaction time and memory. However, green tea contains more than just caffeine. It also has the amino acid L-theanine, which has anti-anxiety effects. In addition to this, green tea is rich in polyphenols which have effects like reducing inflammation. Green tea has been shown to boost the metabolic rate and increase fat burning in the short term, although not all studies agree.
Now that you've discovered super-powered health benefits of green tea, go make yourself a cuppa.
Boosts immunity
A super source of antioxidants
Improves brain health and memory!
Nutritious Things Come in Small Packages.

These tiny little gems pack a potent punch. Ranking the highest of any fruit for antioxidants. Interestingly so there is a serious and bizarre amount of interesting evidence in support of eating an abundance of blueberries. From things like improving memory to reducing depression, to preventing diabetes. There are actually nutrition scientists who have devoted their careers to studying blueberries.
If any fruit is deserving of
superfruit
status, she concluded, it actually may be the blueberry.
Add blueberries as your topping of choice to your favourite breakfast cereal or sprinkle them over a green salad.
Tip: Keep your blueberries fresh by keeping them dry, avoid rinsing them until you're ready to eat them.
Rich in iron
Improves energy levels.
High in Vitamin A, C, and K

Spinach is famously known as a source of Popeye's strength. When faced with the sight of trouble, the influential pipe-smoking sailor would burst open a tin of spinach. Once consumed, his biceps would bulge and his new found strength would see him overcome his enemies.

This low calorie superfood is known for its remarkable abilities to restore energy, increase vitality and improve the quality of the blood. There are sound reasons why spinach would produce such results, primarily the fact that it is rich in iron. Iron plays a central role in the function of red blood cells which help in transporting oxygen around the body, in energy production and DNA synthesis. Spinach is also an excellent source of vitamin K, vitamin A, vitamin C and folate as well as being a good source of manganese, magnesium, iron and vitamin B2.
Tip...
...Don't be shy with your portions when cooking spinach. Its high water content means it reduces in size by about a quarter when cooked.
Improves Heart Health.
Protects Against Skin Damage.
Antibacterial, Antifungal, and Antiviral properties.
Boost your immune system and remove toxins from your body with this clever fruit.
This exquisite tropical fruit, native to Central America has a healthy dose of Vitamin C, which improves immune function and lowers the risk of several diseases.

In addition, to keeping your body healthy, papaya can also help your skin look more toned and radiant. Excessive free radical activity is believed to be responsible for much of the wrinkling, and sagging skin damage that occurs with aging. Papaya is rich in antioxidants, such as Lycopene, which is known to help protect skin from the harmful rays of the sun. This antioxidant may also help protect your skin against the visible signs of aging!
Alongside Lycopene and Vitamin C, Papayas contain high levels of antioxidants such as Vitamin A, Vitamin C, and Vitamin E. Diets high in these antioxidants
may reduce the risk of heart disease.
Treat yourself by adding this healthy and delicious fruit to your lifestyle today!
Tip: The best way to enjoy the fruit is raw when it is ripe. However, due to the presence of Latex in Papaya, pregnant women are advised to avoid the fruit.
High Vitamin K content.
Helps to manage blood sugar levels.
High in fibre.

Brussels sprouts are more than just tiny cabbages, these bad boys are packed with nutrients and minerals, including manganese, copper, phosphorus and iron, all of which are needed to build strong bones and prevent the onset of osteoporosis. By preventing bone mineral density loss, a diet rich in Brussels Sprouts can keep you feeling healthy and active as you age. Not only are Brussels sprouts nutrient-dense, but they also help maintain healthy blood sugar and blood pressure levels.
Brussels sprouts are named after the fact that they were cultivated in Belgium in the 16th century. Knowing this little fact will also help you remember that it’s Brussels sprouts,
not
Brussel sprouts.

Don't like eating seafood? Thankfully Brussels sprouts are a great alternative Brussels sprouts are your answer. Omega-3 fatty acids have been shown to slow cognitive decline and decrease inflammation, with fresh seafood being the best place to get the fatty acids.
Did you know that food rich in antioxidants reduce the oxidative stress in your cells and lower your risk of chronic disease?
Tip: Balance out the bitterness of these sprouts using lemon juice and zest. Even better when Honey and Parmesan are added too.
High antioxidant content.
Helps to manage blood sugar levels.
High calcium, phosphorus and manganese content.

Chia seeds have exploded in popularity in recent years. A key reason may be their reputation as nutritional powerhouses. These seeds loaded with nutrients that can have important benefits for your body and brain.
Almost all of the carbohydrates in chia seeds are fibre. This gives them the ability to absorb 10–12 times their weight in water. Fibre also has various beneficial effects on health.
The name 'chia' was given to the seeds and means 'strength' in ancient Mayan, as they were prized for their ability to provide sustainable energy.
Add chia seeds to foods you're already eating -- as a topping on yogurt, mixed into bread dough, or tossed into muffin or pancake batter.
Also known as Filberts.
Loaded With antioxidants.
Hazelnuts are a good source of dietary fibre.
Hazelnuts are not only a delicious snack, but they provide a range of nutritional benefits, including a high content of protein, healthy fats, and vitamins and minerals.
You can improve your heart health simply by including a handful of hazelnuts in your diet. Hazelnuts do this by lowering blood pressure, reducing inflammation and balancing cholesterol levels.

One cup of hazelnuts offers about 86% of the daily Vitamin E requirement. It also contains Vitamin A and Vitamin C, two powerful antioxidants. A synergic effect of these vitamins prevents the onset of fine lines and wrinkles on your skin, thus delaying the early onset of ageing signs. Hazelnuts, as mentioned above, contain vitamin E in plentiful amounts.

This Vitamin E along with the fats of this nut helps in moisturising and hydrating the skin. It, thus, conditions the skin, keeping it soft and smooth. The skin looks visibly radiant with the slightest tint of greasiness appearing nowhere.

You can apply hazelnut oil on your skin. This will act as a natural sunscreen, safeguarding you from the harmful effects of the harsh UV rays. Just mix a few drops each of sesame, avocado, walnut, and hazelnut oils and apply this mixed oil in your skin daily to get protection from UV rays.
Free Radical Fighter
May boost heart health
May improve gut health and digestion
Native to Australia, macadamia trees are now grown in various places around the world, including Brazil, Indonesia, Kenya, New Zealand and South Africa.
These fancy nuts are known to be the most expensive nuts in the world!

Considered a high-quality treat due to their rich, buttery flavour, macadamia nuts are a popular treat, yet rare find around the world. These desired desserts, require the virtue of patience, as it takes between seven to 10 years for the trees to even begin producing nuts, and that's before the slow harvesting process!

A real heart hero! Macadamia nuts have had a bad reputation for a long time, due to their high-fat content. However, the macadamia might be more nutritious than once suspected. Don't listen to the gossip though, this type of fat can help to reduce your risk of Heart Disease and Type 2 Diabetes. Around 80 percent of the fat is monounsaturated (the good type of fat). Also rich in oleic acid, macadamias contain a type of monounsaturated fatty acid linked to reduced risk of cardiovascular disease. In addition, macadamia nuts are one of the only food sources that contain palmitoleic acid (a type of monounsaturated fatty acid that may speed up fat metabolism, thus reducing the body’s ability to store fat).

It is because of their high content of monounsaturated fat, that macadamia nut oil is fast becoming a favourite among chefs around the world. Not only is it healthier than olive oil and canola oil, but many people also believe that it has a better taste. In addition to this, macadamia nut oil has a higher smoke point than olive oil, which means that it can be cooked at higher temperatures without breaking down and losing its flavour.
However, when it comes to eating Macadamia nuts in their solid form, some studies
suggest that roasting Macadamia nuts, especially at higher temperatures, can reduce their nutrient content. Consider, consuming them raw or soaked to obtain the best benefits.

Tip: If you're not planning on eating your Macadamia friends in the next two to three weeks, freezing is recommended. The high-fat content can go rancid very quickly if left at warm temperatures for too long.

name.en-US: Water You Talking About (High Water Content)

content.value: Selenium is a mineral that is not present in most fruits and vegetables but can be found in mushrooms. It plays a role in liver enzyme function, and helps detoxify some cancer-causing compounds in the body. Additionally, selenium prevents inflammation and also decreases tumor
growth rates.
Sickness Saviour
Reduces Blood Pressure
Boosts mood and improves brain health
This impressive and loyal little herbal healing companion that’s easy to get your hands on anytime and anywhere. Even on vacation!

Widely used as a flavouring in cooking, garlic has also been used as a medicine throughout ancient and modern history. This germ fighter has been known to prevent and treat a wide range of conditions and boost the immune system.
Garlic contains compounds that help the immune system fight germs. Whole garlic contains a compound called alliin. When garlic is crushed or chewed, this compound turns into allicin (with a '
c'

), the main active ingredient in garlic. Allicin gives garlic its distinctive smell and taste and converts into other sulphur-containing compounds which are believed to boost the disease-fighting response of some types of white blood cells in the body when they encounter viruses, such as the viruses that cause the common cold or flu.

Garlic is packed full of nutrients and adds intense flavour to any dish. It’s the most potent when used in its raw form. One benefit of raw garlic is that its fill of vitamins and minerals,  including vitamin B6, manganese, selenium, vitamin c, iron, potassium, and copper. This powerhouse combination is especially good for cognitive function: Vitamin B6 and magnesium are both linked to boosting mood and improving brain health.
Tip: Finely chop or crush garlic and add to your cooking just before you serve for maximum benefit.
High in fibre
Turnips have a long shelf life.
Excellent source of Vitamin K, Vitamin A and Vitamin C

During the Middle Ages, the turnip was notorious in Europe as a popular vegetable often eaten by the lower economic class. Today, the turnip is widely enjoyed in a variety of dishes. Turnip is available year-round. When buying this multi-purpose vegetable, you will have the option of small and large turnips. The younger, smaller turnips will have a sweeter flavour to them, compared to the stronger and more woody taste of the larger ones. Another advantage of this super vege, is that the whole turnip can be eaten! The bulb is high in Vitamin C, while the greens are a good source of Vitamins C and K, Folate and Calcium. Also, high in fibre, a diet filled with turnips  can help to relieve constipation and promote regularity.

Tip: Though they are most commonly cooked, turnips can be enjoyed raw as well. If you plan to eat them raw, simply peel and slice the turnip like an apple to eat with dips or add to the top of your salad.
Helps stabilise blood pressure
This burly boy helps to keep you alert, energetic, and in great shape!
Also known as German turnip, but despite its name, kohlrabi is not a root vegetable.

Known for its bizarre appearance but extremely hardy nature, this unique vegetable is certainly not lacking in flavour and nutrition, making it highly deserving of your attention (and a space in your pantry). At first glance, who doesn’t wonder, what the heck is that? The word “kohlrabi” is German in origin, “kohl” meaning cabbage and “rübe” meaning turnip. Although early in its classification it was thought to be a cross between a cabbage and a turnip, its genetics stem from the same common wild cabbage. Kohlrabi is rich in Potassium, one of the key players in muscle and nerve behaviour in the body.

This means that eating Kohlrabi may help us move, breathe, react, and function every single day. In addition to its impact on energy levels, Kohlrabi also regulates blood pressure and  increases circulation throughout the body.
High in healthy fats.
Hemp seeds are a great source of plant-based protein.
Contain high amounts of both soluble and insoluble fibre.

Hemp is commonly confused with marijuana and while it belongs to the same family, the two plants are very different. Marijuana is grown to contain high amounts of tetrahydrocannabinol (THC), the chemical that is responsible for its mind-altering properties. Hemp, describes the edible plant seeds and only contains a trace amount of THC.

These small, brown seeds are rich in protein, fibre, and fatty acids, including omega-3 and omega-6. They have antioxidant effects and may reduce symptoms of numerous ailments, improving the health of the heart, skin, and joints.
Hemp seeps are exceptionally nutritious and rich in healthy fats, protein and minerals.

Hemp seeds are a complete source of protein. This means that they provide all nine essential amino acids. Few plant-based foods are complete sources of protein, making hemp seeds a valuable addition to a vegetarian or vegan diet.
These nutritious seeds contain most of their goodness in the outer hull, or shell.
Tip: To maximise the goodness you get from these powerful seeds, purchase hemp with the hulls intact.

Zinc is considered an essential nutrient, meaning that the body can’t produce or store it. This trace mineral is essential for good health, meaning that it is important to include it in your everyday diet in order to meet your daily requirements. This mineral metabolises nutrients, sustains the immune system and grows and repairs body tissues. Whilst vital for a healthy immune system, it is important to note, that Zinc can only be taken in small does. Zinc is essential for synthesising DNA, promoting healthy growth during childhood, and healing wounds.
Anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties
Contains Curcumin which is known for its medicinal properties.
Requires a carrier oil for maximum absorption.

Many people know Turmeric as the spice that gives curry its yellow colour. However, this bad boy has more than meets the eye. Used in India for thousands of years as both a spice and medicinal herb, Turmeric is beginning to regain in popularity. Science has started to back up what Indians have known for a long time — it really does contain compounds with medicinal properties. Curcumin is the main active ingredient in Turmeric. It has powerful anti-inflammatory effects and dramatically increases the antioxidant capacity of the body. This powdered spice (or freshly grated root) is a great addition to soups and smoothies, sprinkle over roast veg, mix into a mash, include in your marinade. You can even use it as a natural food colouring!

Tip: Spice up your life by adding a dash of Turmeric in your coffee or meal, but don't forget to use a carrier oil. In order to get maximum absorption, mix this fat-soluble superstar works best with fats such as Coconut or Jojoba Oil.
Anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial and antioxidant properties
Packed with powerful antioxidants, such as polyphenols
Cinnamon reduces insulin resistance, helping this important hormone do its job!
This highly delicious spice has been prized for its medicinal properties for thousands of years. Cinnamon is a spice that is made from the inner bark of trees scientifically known as
Cinnamomum

. It has been used as an ingredient throughout history, dating back as far as Ancient Egypt. It used to be rare and valuable and was regarded as a gift fit for kings.
Cinnamon is made by cutting the stems of cinnamon trees. The inner bark is then extracted and the woody parts removed. When it dries, it forms strips that curl into rolls, called cinnamon sticks. These sticks can be ground to form cinnamon powder.
There are two main types of cinnamon.
Ceylon cinnamon (also known as "true" cinnamon)
Cassia cinnamon (The more common variety today and what people generally refer to as "cinnamon)

If possible choose the Ceylon variety of cinnamon and enjoy with all manner of foods – have a teaspoon in a smoothie; sprinkle over nut butter on sliced apple pieces or into blended frozen banana (the fabulous ‘nice-cream’ ice cream alternative); stir into stews, soups, bolognese, curries; add to steam veg, roast veg, mashed veg. The options are endless with cinnamon!
Best when raw!
Improves heart and nerve function.
Super easy to grow in your garden and incorporate into your diet.
If its peppery punch wasn't enough to send you to the grocery store before, perhaps you'll change your mind as you read about its nutrient profile.

Arugula has a history in folk medicine, for treating and preventing skin conditions such as eczema, dry skin, and acne. The addition of Arugula leaves and seed oil into the diet can protect the skin from UV rays and their effects. This is because Arugula is full of antioxidants and anti-inflammatory compounds. It is also said to boost cell resilience and elasticity. When consumed regularly, you can harness anti-aging benefits, too.
Pregnancy is that time wherein expecting mothers should eat more Iron, Folate, Calcium, Vitamins A, B, and C, Magnesium, and Zinc. All these nutrients can be found in a good dose in Arugula.

Eat Arugula for a happy heart! This virtuous vegetable contains a high amount of Vitamin C, Vitamin K, and Folate – the heart-friendly nutrients. Vitamin K, in turn, boosts heart health by pushing calcium into the bones, instead of flushing it into your arteries and block circulation. This sweetheart is also high in chlorophyll, which helps prevent liver and DNA damage.

Tip: To get the most chlorophyll in Arugula, it is best to eat it raw. Enjoy this spicy leaf pureed into a pesto with a kick, tossed onto whole-wheat pizza once it emerges from the oven, or used in a variety of tossed salads.
Improves digestive health.
High in fibre and omega-3 fatty acids
Ground flaxseed is easier to digest than whole flaxseed.

Flaxseeds, also known as linseeds are emerging as a “superfood”. Grown since the beginning of civilization, flax seeds are one of the oldest crops. There are two types, brown and golden, which are equally nutritious.

With a lot of people going for meatless Mondays and eating more plant-based meals in general, flaxseed meal is on the list of protein sources. No, you cannot replace a protein meal with flaxseed, but it is a way to add it to your meal.

Flaxseeds are also very high in fibre and are one of the best plant-based sources of heart-healthy Omega 3 Fatty Acids. Omega 3 Fatty Acids can help reduce inflammation (which can contribute to heart disease), help fight autoimmune diseases, and may reduce the risk of certain cancers

To ensure you are getting the most benefit out of flaxseed,  it must be ground or crushed. This is because the body cannot break down the whole flaxseed to access the omega-3-containing oil. You can purchase flaxseed whole or ground as flaxseed meal. Whole seeds, oftentimes less expensive, can be ground using a coffee grinder or food processor. Once ground, flaxseed should be stored in the refrigerator in an airtight, non-transparent container, as they are much more prone to oxidation and spoilage.
Tip: Add a tablespoon of ground flaxseed to your hot or cold breakfast cereal for improved digestive health. But make sure to grind the flaxseeds first as they are much better to absorb this way.
Anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties
Contains Gingerol which is known for its medicinal properties.
Helps relieve pain, soothes digestive system and alleviates mild nausea

Ginger has been hailed by cultures worldwide since ancient times. This peppery spice, containing therapeutic properties has been used in traditional medicine in its various forms. Ginger can be used fresh, dried, powdered, or as an oil. This  well known home remedy has been used for centuries for treating nausea and stomach pain and even in pregnancy. Ginger has been found recently to not only reduce PMS severity, but also reduces the duration of menstruation in women, reducing overall blood loss. Like its close relative, turmeric, it is a very common ingredient in recipes. The unique fragrance and flavour of ginger come from its natural oils, the most important of which is gingerol. Gingerol is the main bioactive compound in ginger, responsible for much of its medicinal properties. It has powerful anti-inflammatory and antioxidant effects.
Reduces inflammation.
Both the stalk and the root can be used.
Different colours preferred in different countries.

Celery was first used as food in Italy in the Middle Ages. White celery, which farmers grew away from the sunlight, was the most common variety, and it is still popular in Europe. A green-stemmed celery was developed in the United States and was successfully introduced into New Zealand in the 1960s. New Zealanders prefer celery to be bright green. Varieties are now available with little or no stringiness. In North America the stalk is used. In Europe the
knobbly root is used. The leaves are strongly flavoured and are used less often, either as a flavouring in soups and stews or as a dried herb.

Celery contains vitamin C, beta carotene, and flavonoids, but there is a wide range of antioxidant nutrients found in a single stalk. It’s also a wonderful source of phytonutrients, which have been shown to reduce instances of inflammation in the digestive tract, cells, blood vessels, and organs.
Dandelion tea is rich in vitamins A, C and D.
Dandelion has long been used in herbal medicine.
It improves appetite and soothes digestive ailments.
Dandelions are more than a pesky weed in your lawn. From root to flower, these highly nutritious plants, are loaded with vitamins, minerals and fibre.

Native to Asia and Europe, the use of dandelion as a herbal medicine has been recorded in ancient writings. Arabian physicians used the medicinal properties of the plant during the tenth and eleventh centuries. The Chinese and Indians have also been known to use dandelion to treat liver diseases and digestive problems.

This powerhouse has broad applications for health,. Full of potent antioxidants, dandelion contains high levels of beta-carotene, which is known to provide strong protection against cellular damage and oxidative stress. In addition to this, dandelion are also rich in another category of antioxidants called polyphenols, which are found in the highest concentration in the flower but are present in the roots, leaves and stems as well.

Dandelion tea can have many positive effects on your digestive system. It improves appetite and soothes digestive ailments. Dandelion tea helps with mineral absorption and soothes the stomach lining. Dandelion tea can help prevent urinary tract infections, as well as bladder disorders, kidney problems As well as Urinary Tract Infections.
Dandelion greens can be eaten cooked or raw and serve as an excellent source of vitamins A, C and K. They also contain vitamin E, folate and small amounts of other B vitamins.
Why not add them to your next salad?
Gluten Free and hypoallergenic.
Contains Copper which many westerners lack.
Helps stabilise blood pressure and reduce cholesterol.
Despite its name, buckwheat is not related to wheat and is thus gluten-free.

This nutrition powerhouse, is cheap and easy to prepare. Due to its high mineral and antioxidant content, Buckwheat has become increasingly popular as a health food. Packed with vitamins and minerals which help with weight loss, lower cholesterol and prevent blood clots. Buckwheat is high in resistant fibre and tannins, which lowers the growth of viral and bacterial infections. The edible part of the plant is the seed which is also called 'groats'. To harness the power of this pseudocereal for yourself, cook whole groats at a ratio of 1:2 with water, and simmer for 30 minutes or until the grains are tender. The groats can also be ground into a gluten-free flour.
Cleanses the skin from within.
Reduce depression related to chronic stress
Effective inflammation remedy for headaches and insomnia.

One of the oldest herbs known to the mankind, the benefits of basil leaves are abundant.  Here are some you may not have known. Basil fortifies the digestive and nervous system and can be a good remedy for headaches and insomnia. The eugenol present in the leaves ensures anti-inflammatory action in the digestive tract. It can be compared to aspirin or ibuprofen. Basil's essential oil may help manage depression and anxiety too. The herb is believed to stimulate neurotransmitters that regulate the hormones responsible for inducing happiness and energy. Basil is considered as a powerful adaptogen or an anti-stress agent. Its anti-inflammatory and immune-boosting properties help manage stress too. As a good source of Magnesium, basil is also known to promote blood flow.

Basil is also an excellent skin cleanser is perfect for those with oily skin. It also helps remove dirt and impurities that clog pores. Make a paste of basil leaves, sandalwood paste and rose water. Apply the paste on your face and let it sit for 20 minutes. Was it off with cold water. The strong anti-inflammatory and antimicrobial properties of basil would help prevent formation of acne.
Tips: Basil is sensitive to the cold, so pick it right before you want to use it. Otherwise, store stalks at room temperature in a glass of water.
Helps your stress levels
High in Potassium. Good for heart health.
Celeriac is high in fibre and a good source of Vitamins B6, C and K.

Celeriac is a relatively unknown vegetable, though its popularity is increasing today, due to it's impressive health benefits. It might look like a Mandrake from Harry Potter’s herbology class, but celery root (also known as celeriac) won’t kill you. This delicious, cheap vegetable is like most root vegetables, super versatile and especially useful during the winter.

So, what is celeriac? Celeriac is actually a type of celery—but it won’t grow into the light green stalks you’re used to chomping down on. Rather, it’s a bulbous veggie about the size of a grapefruit and has a
mild, slightly sweet, celery-like flavour. It’s easy to prepare, simply
cut off the top and bottom and stand it on a cutting board. Now you’re ready to peel off the knobby, brown skin with a knife.
You can bake, boil, fry, or steam celeriac. Some people also mash celeriac and serve it as a side dish or chop it for inclusion in soups.
Give it a wash
and you’re good to go.
Tip: Try Celeriac as a low-carb alternative to potatoes.
Free radical fighters.
Enhances digestion and nourishes gut bacteria
Contains prebiotics and encourages the growth of the probiotics
Dragon Fruit is a food that demands attention!
This increasingly popular fruit can be quite a rare find in supermarkets. It grows on the
Hylocereus
cactus, also known as the 'Honolulu Queen', whose flowers only open at night.
However, as exotic as it may appear, Its taste can be described as a combination of a kiwi and a pear.

Also known as 'Pitahaya' or 'Strawberry Pear', this is a tropical fruit known for its vibrant red skin and sweet, seed-speckled pulp. This high in fibre fruit, keeps you fuller for longer between meals. It also has a prebiotic effect on the body that enhances digestion and nourishes gut bacteria. Specifically, Dragon Fruit encourages the growth of Lactobacilli and Bifidobacteria, which can kill disease-causing viruses and bacteria. Rich in antioxidants.
This sassy fruit helps to keep you youthful by protecting your cells from damage by free radicals. Dragon Fruit makes for a great snack
or dessert because it's naturally fat-free. To eat it, simply cut open the juicy fruit, and you'll find fleshy white stuff inside dotted with edible black seeds.
Tip: For a mid-meal treat, scoop out the flesh and enjoy the fruit fresh, or perhaps with a drizzle of honey. The outer skin is inedible though, so avoid it.
Improves digestion.
Not a fruit, nor a vegetable.
Jackfruit can be eaten in a variety of ways.

Jackfruit is an exotic fruit grown in tropical regions of the world. The fleshy part (the “bulb”) can be eaten as is, or cut up and cooked. When unripe (green), it is remarkably similar in texture to chicken, making jackfruit an excellent vegetarian substitute for meat. Jackfruit has a subtle sweet and fruity flavour. It has been said to taste similar to a combination of fruits, including apples, pineapples, mangoes and bananas.

Like all fruits, jackfruit supplies plenty of nutritional perks: It’s low in calories, naturally fat- and sodium-free, provides ample Vitamin A (in the form of beta-carotene) and Vitamin C. Jackfruit contains a high amount of Vitamin C and antioxidants which helps boost your immune system and makes it stronger when fighting an infection. It also packs in a surprising blood pressure-lowering Potassium. It's also rich in fibre, which means it can help you feel satisfied on fewer calories.

Jackfruit is rich in two kinds of fibres- soluble and insoluble. It is very important to eat a healthy amount of fibres in your daily meal. The soluble fibre is quickly broken down by our body to produce energy and the insoluble fibre adds bulk to your stool thereby easing up your bowel movement.
Strong smelling fruit
Lowers blood sugar levels and control blood pressure,
Helps with bone and skin health.

Nicknamed 'the king of fruits', Durian is known for its strong smell and high nutritional value. This tropical fruit is distinguished by its large size and spiky, hard outer shell. Durian is used in sweet and savoury dishes. The flavour is described as tasting like cheese, almonds, garlic, and caramel all at once. Both the creamy flesh and seeds are edible, though the seeds need to be cooked. One of the benefits of Durian fruit is its high fibre content. It is also worth noting that with an average 1 kg sized durian having close to 1,350 calories, this thiamin fighter should be eaten is small doses unless you are actively trying to gain weight. It may also be an idea to avoid when consuming alcohol as some scientists believe that sulfur-like compounds in durian may prevent certain enzymes from breaking down alcohol, causing increased alcohol levels in your blood. The more you know!
Improves memory
Kidney beans are rich in protein
Raw or improperly cooked kidney beans are toxic,
The
kidney bean
is a variety of the common bean
It is named for its visual resemblance in shape and colour to a kidney. This fibre all star offers extraordinary health benefits.
Like it's siblings, Kidney beans are a great source of cholesterol-lowering fibre.

In addition to lowering cholesterol, kidney beans' high fibre content prevents blood sugar levels from rising too rapidly after a meal, making these beans an especially good choice for individuals with diabetes. When combined with whole grains such as rice, kidney beans provide virtually fat-free high quality protein.

However,  this is far from all kidney beans have to offer. Kidney beans are high in protein, which helps to stabilise blood sugar. They also improves heart health due to their high fibre and folate levels.
Pop some of these reddish brown beans into your next meal for a protein punch and you certainly won't regret it!
Perfect protein supplement for all!
Anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties
Boosts metabolism and increased energy levels

Spirulina is the detoxing queen of all functional foods. It contains one of the highest densities of protein found in any food, offers more beta-carotene than carrots, more iron than raw spinach, and more calcium than milk, on gram per gram basis. Its wealth of nutrients is unparalleled. When consumed with dark leafy green vegetables, spirulina induces the detoxification process in the body. Spirulina makes for an excellent dietary supplement for people on vegetarian or vegan diets because of its high vitamin content.

This powerful immunity agent is actually an algae, and we admit sometimes that it sure tastes like it! Try out this smoothie if you’re game. It actually tastes pretty good, and the health benefits will leave you feeling amazing too!
Free radical warrior and fat fighter!
Energy without the anxiety, crash or jitters.
Like yoga for your brain - Matcha encourages relaxation and mental clarity.
Matcha tea is said to be the healthiest drink on the planet.
Give your mind and body an instant boost and possibly even add a new meaning to your day by popping this bad boy into your daily routine.
Matcha is a form of green tea that’s been enjoyed in Asia for hundreds of years. The leaves are made into a powder that’s far stronger than regular tea, so a little can go a long way.

It is known for giving clean energy without excessive caffeine, sugar content and unknown chemicals. The combination of caffeine with l-theanine in matcha green tea provides a stable and extended boost of energy without the anxious jitters or side effects like you might have previously experienced with coffee and energy drinks.

The combination of caffeine and l-theanine do wonders for concentration. Drinking a cup of matcha, boosts the production of alpha waves in the brain, thus encouraging relaxation and inducing a profound feeling of mental clarity and a more alert state of mind - the same mental state can be found in meditation and yoga practice.

Not only is it good for your brain, it is also great for your body. Packed with antioxidants, Matcha protects your cells from damage. Some studies show that because of the way it’s made, matcha may have more of those than loose-leaf green tea.
Matcha green tea fortifies the immune system and limits the invasion and growth of viruses and bacteria in the body.
Supports nerve and muscle function
Also known as 'Chard' and 'Swiss Chard'.
Silverbeet will be among the first crops grown on planetary space stations.

Often the forgotten leafy green that sits wallowing on the shelf, while its relative’s kale and spinach take all of the supermarket glory riding smugly in health conscious peoples shopping trolleys off to the checkout. Silverbeet is leafy green vegetable that was named differently to other same plant varieties because of the colour of its stalk ironically.
This multipurpose super green has high levels of magnesium, calcium, potassium and others that are necessary in helping you with muscle health and also with your nervous system health.
Silverbeet is a highly nutritious vegetable is a good source of vitamins A, B6, C and K as well as riboflavin and folate. Silverbeet is at its peak between March and August.

The higher than normal magnesium levels also have other benefits for you, it may help with reduction of muscle cramps, reducing stress levels, insomnia related issues, moods and also assisting with blood pressure regulation.
Natural expectorant for chest congestion
Sunflower Microgreens are a great source of complete protein.
Helps to repair muscle tissue and aid in enzymatic functions in the body

These tender greens offer a slightly almond flavour and are a cinch to grow. Whole-food aficionados give sunflower sprouts high marks in the flavour department, rating them tastier than more common sprouts — like wheat, mung or cress. The taste blends nuttiness with a hint of lemon, and the sprout serves a more toothsome bite than wispy alfalfa sprouts. Containing both Vitamin E and Vitamin C, the two work synergistically with selenium to reduce blood pressure, increase the elasticity of arteries and prevent heart disease. Sunflower microgreens are a natural expectorant for chest congestion.
Known for relieving pain and inflammation.
Anti-mutagenic and anti-microbial properties.
Cloves contain a compound called eugenol, which acts as a natural antioxidant.

When you stock up your spice rack, your first priority is probably to make sure the basics are covered: garlic powder, a little cayenne when you want a kick of heat, turmeric for your anti-inflammatory lattes, and, of course, salt and pepper. But, the next time you’re on a mission to rebuild your inventory, you might consider adding another health-benefiting staple to your cart: cloves.
Cloves might not be a common ingredient in your recipes (yet!), but they’re more than worthy of having a spot in your diet. Cloves are a

spice that are native to Asian countries such as Indonesia and India. They offer many benefits that include aiding in digestion, boosting the immune system, and controlling diabetes. Cloves also contain anti-mutagenic & anti-microbial properties and are also thought to display aphrodisiac properties.
They’re also a notable ingredient in Ayurveda and traditional Chinese medicine, thanks to their many pain-relieving abilities. Give them a go!

Tip: Buy whole buds instead of powder since oftentimes it may contain adulterated spicy powders. The buds should be wholesome with stem and sepals, and compact. Good quality buds should release sweet fragrance when squeezed between the thumb and index fingers.
Contain long lasting (bound) antioxidants.
Pineapples contain digestive enzymes known as bromelain
Eating pineapples may reduce the time it takes to recover from surgery or exercise.

More than meets the eye, Pineapple is more than just a delicious tropical meal — it offers significant health benefits as well. In particular, Pineapples contain bromelain, which breaks down protein into its building blocks, including amino acids. This aids the digestion and absorption of proteins. Pineapple is also one of the top food sources of Manganese, with a single cup of pineapple contains about 76 percent of the recommended daily value of Manganese.
This sweetie is also known for it's ability to make you taste sweet. Studies have shown that eating pineapple can make bodily fluids taste sweeter. Why not give it a try?

Pineapples are also especially rich in antioxidants known as flavonoids and phenolic acids. What’s more, many of the antioxidants in pineapple are bound. This allows the antioxidants to survive harsher conditions in the body and produce longer-lasting effects.

Before you go off frolicking with your newfound knowledge, get ready to have your mind blown and your childish innocence shattered. Pineapple not actually a fruit at all, rather it is a berry. Yes, you read that right, a berry.

This juicy berry can be enjoyed in many forms. You can grill slices and serve them with meat or as a tasty side, or can toss frozen chunks into a smoothie. You can also, of course, snack on bite-sized pieces. No matter how you prefer to eat it, you’ll want to begin incorporating pineapple into your diet if you haven’t already.
wh food pineapple

Tip: Pineapple can be stored in the refrigerator for five to seven days if it is trimmed and cut, covered in juice correctly in an airtight container. Let the fruit return to room temperature before eating to improve flavor.
High in Vitamin C
Contain many essential nutrients.
Also known as 'Rutabaga', 'Neep', or 'Swedish Turnip'.

Swedes are root vegetables that belong to the cabbage family. They are often confused with turnips as both vegetables share so many similarities and people often question whether it's a Swede or Turnip so to clarify this matter, Swede is generally larger in size, it is round in shape and has tough pink, purple, or white shades of skin. The flesh of a Swede is generally white or yellow in colour. Swedes and turnips are so closely related that some regard them as the same vegetable. For example, Scotland, where they are known as 'Neeps'. Sometimes swede is known by other names including swede-turnips or Swedish turnips.
They are extremely nutritious and well known for their antioxidant content.
The word “Rutabaga” comes from the Swedish “rotabagge,” which means
root ram, thick root, ram’s foot
, or
baggy root.

Rutabagas are only called rutabagas in the United States of America, throughout the rest of the world, they’re known as Swedes. This root vegetable is supposed to have originated in Bohemia in the 17th century as a hybrid between the turnip and wild cabbage. Not to be confused with its relative the Turnip; Rutabagas are actually larger, denser and higher in many essential nutrients
It can be used as an alternative to mashed potato, or in stews and soups. Swede is also brilliant when cut up into wedges, roasted, and tossed through a salad or stirred into a veggie curry.
Tip: If you want to get creative in the kitchen, Swedes are a great ingredient to experiment with. Try them with carrots or parsnips in your next dish, these pairings are divine!
Disease-fighting
High in antioxidants
Inflammation fighter and high blood pressure reducer
Level up with this native Mediterranean plant!
Often labeled as one of the most powerful disease-fighting plants, parsley provides great nutritional value and offers many potential health benefits.

Two of the most powerful antioxidants for the body are beta-carotene and Vitamin C, and Parsley has high levels of both! Alongside this power couple, as well as  Luteolin and Zeaxanthin, two other good food sources, help Parsley to treat conditions like high blood pressure, allergies, and inflammatory diseases over the years. Today, it’s widely used as a fresh culinary herb or dried spice. It’s bright green in colour and has a mild, bitter flavor that pairs well with many recipes.

The herb is rich in many vitamins, particularly Vitamin K, a nutrient that supports bone and heart health. In fact, just two tablespoons (8 grams) of Parsley deliver more Vitamin K than you need in a day!

Include this powerful herb contains antioxidants that prevent cellular damage from molecules called free radicals. Parsley may help keep your kidneys healthy by fighting inflammation and reducing high blood pressure and your risk of kidney stones. Interestingly, dried parsley may be higher in antioxidants than fresh sprigs.
Elevate the flavor of your next dish by adding Parsley as a garnish on pasta or soups.
