Tip: Fresh parsley is highly fragile, so give it a gentle wash right before using it.
Loaded with beta-carotene
Helps to prevent oxidative stress damage.
Anti-inflammotary and anti-bacterial properties.

Paprika is made from grinding capsicum peppers into a fine powder. It adds vibrant red colour as well as a rich, pungent flavor to a variety of meals. Simply add a single tablespoon serving to your next dish and you will receive not only compliments, but also, ample amounts of several beneficial nutrients!

Paprika is loaded with Beta-carotene and Iron, as well as many other vitamins. It helps you prevent freckles as well as age spots from forming as the production of the skin-darkening agent, Melanin, is limited. This helps to keep your complexion in good shape and free of age spots. After all, age spots are a result of being in the sun for prolonged periods of time. If you enjoy being outdoors, make sure to use your sunscreen and use Paprika to your advantage.

Carotenoids are the primary source of antioxidants when it comes to Paprika. These pigments do great things for your body as they may prevent oxidative stress damage, as well as help the body fight disease.

Keeping your skin clean and free of germs is crucial, so you don’t get sick. Skin issues caused by bacteria could be remedied with Paprika. For instance, some people are affected by acne, so adding a little bit of Paprika to your food could help you clear this up.
So, how will you choose to integrate Paprika into your life?
Tip: Consume a healthy fat like avocado along with your Paprika to take advantage of this benefit, as antioxidants are fat-soluble.

You may not have heard of the trace mineral Molybdenum, but it is an essential mineral in the body, just like Iron and Magnesium. Though your body only needs tiny amounts, it’s a key component of many essential functions. Without it, sulfites and toxins would build up in your body. Molybdenum is an essential mineral in the body, just like iron and magnesium.

It is present in soil and transferred into your diet when you consume plants, as well as animals that feed on those plants. Although amounts vary, the richest sources are usually beans, lentils, and grains.
Reducing menstrual pain.
Promotes Sleep and may treat Insomnia
Lowers blood sugar and possible treatment for Diabetes.

Imagine this, you've had a long day, and make a cup of Chamomile Tea and settle on the couch with a cozy blanket, a good book, and that steaming mug. Sounds relaxing, doesn't it? It's not just the ritual providing that calming effect. Chamomile has a stellar reputation for healing, and with good reason.
Chamomile Tea relaxes nerves, soothes the nervous system, and to top it off is free from caffeine! Making this hot brew best consumed before sleeping.
Chamomile Tea contains Chamazulene, an aromatic chemical compound that possesses anti-inflammatory, analgesic, and antispasmodic properties. The benefits of chamomile tea are in abundance.

Many studies have shown that Chamomile tea will not only kick illnesses to the curb but also work as a great preventive measure. It fights harmful bacteria and has the ability to boost your immune system.

Several studies have linked chamomile tea to the reduced severity of menstrual cramps. A study found that consuming chamomile tea for a month could reduce the pain of menstrual cramps. Women in the study also reported less anxiety
and distress associated with period pain.
Tip: If you want to make Cold-Brew Chamomile, simply put Chamomile Tea and water in a pitcher or glass container. Cover and place in the refrigerator to cold brew
Chamomile can be steeped for over 24 hours in the refrigerator and won’t get bitter like black or green tea.
Flavour Enhancer
Natural relief for digestion
Also known as 'Chakra Phool'
The star-shaped spice originated in south China and possesses a flavour to Licorice,  and is called by the name of 'Chakra Phool' in India.
Star anise has a distinct Licorice flavour similar to that of Anise or Fennel, though it’s not related to either of these spices. It pairs well with Coriander, Cinnamon, Cardamon,
and Clove.

In cooking, Star Anise can be used whole or as a powder. It’s often utilized in classical Chinese, Vietnamese, Indian, and Middle Eastern cuisines, especially as a flavour enhancer in broths, soups, and curries.
It’s well known for its presence in the Chinese “5 Spice” and Indian “Garam Masala” blends.

In traditional Chinese and folk medicine practices, Star Anise is steeped in water to make a tea used to treat respiratory infections, nausea, constipation, and other digestive issues. It also can help you get your mojo back if you know what I mean...
Star anise also makes a great addition to sweet dishes and desserts, such as baked fruit, pies, quick bread, and muffins.
If you’ve never used this spice in your culinary pursuits before, keep in mind that a little goes a long way. Start with a small amount and add more to taste in order to avoid using too much.
Tip: Try sprinkling powdered Star Anise into your next batch of muffins or throw a couple of whole pods into your next pot of soup for a warming boost of flavour.

name.en-US: Complete Proteins for Vegetarians and Vegans

content.value: Pantothenic Acid (historically known as Vitamin B5) is among the most essential of the B vitamins for the basic processes of life while also being one of the less likely nutrient deficiencies in the average western diet.

One factor helping to prevent pantothenic acid deficiency is the western diet is its common presence in so many different foods. In fact, the common presence of Pantothenic Acid in foods is referred to in the naming of this vitamin, since the word 'Pantothen
in Greek translates as "on all sides" or "from all "quarters."

Without pantothenic acid, you would be unable to use fats, carbohydrates, or proteins as energy sources. You would also be unable to make hormones and your immune system would collapse. These are only some of the important functions that Pantothenic Acid has.
Three excellent sources of Pantothenic Acid—Cauliflower, Crimini Mushrooms, and, Shiitake Mushrooms.
Pungent flavour
Also known as Wild Leeks
Extremely rare and take many years to grow.
Ramps have long dominated the foodie scene for the past quarter-century, but for those of us who are just tuning in, what exactly are ramps, and why are they so awesome?

Ramps are a wild onion that grows during the spring in Eastern Canada and the U.S. They're sometimes referred to as Wild Leeks, and taste like a balanced mixture of Garlic and Onion. They're pungent, to say the very least.

But some folks find Ramps absolutely adore them. In fact, there's a Twitter account with live updates for ramp availability as these wild plants are scarce. This wild child can take up to four years to flower and are in season for only a few weeks in the spring and are very limited in supply.
This buzz has caused people to over-harvest them, resulting in all kinds of bans that have only heightened the hysteria. In some countries, this ban even resulted in a black market for Ramps.
In summary, people who like ramps don't just like them, they're obsessed with them.
Tip: Rinse them thoroughly before using, and gently pat dry. No, seriously... Ramps have plenty of crevices for mud to hide in and as stated above, they come from the forest floor.
